SEO

SEO from scratch on WordPress

02/05/2014 Chris Lannister Leave a comment

SEO Introduction

Today is an exciting day as my new website is as about as visible to search engines as human rights are in North Korea. However all glory to Kim John Ill and lets begin.

So I begin by by going to a free SEO ranking site such as WebRank Page. I use this site simply because it’s pretty. There are many others out there but this one is mine… Also the free features on this site and not having to sign in is a bonus. I probe my rank and low and behold, I get a C.

Planning content

One of the first issues this site roasts me on is my content, however writing any old rubbish simply isn’t good enough. An important note I want to make is that content of the website is key. There’s websites with poor SEO but still get the views simply because there content is good. It’s important to plan what you want your website content.
For example with my site: the purpose of my site is my portfolio but I also want to create articles based on web design/development subjects to boost views. Also writing stuff down that you’ve learned is a good knowledge reinforcement exercise  and maybe one of these terrible posts will actually help someone.

To help with the SEO side of these articles, I have installed the Yoast WordPress SEO Plugin. I have created a another post on this subject to help users get the most out of this plugin.

Note that your keyword density should be high but shouldn’t harm the integrity of your site. Google also seems to be going from strength to strength in terms of picking up spamming of words.

Social Media

A big part of your search strategy should include social media in some form. In particular, Google + greatly helps your sites visibility.  Hard to believe that Google would favour pages with links coming in from their own social media site? In the wonderful world of WordPress, there is a very valuable set of tools called Jetpack. After a very simple install process, a new menu will appear in your side bar.

Activate the sharing tab and then head to settings – sharing. You can now connect your accounts to WordPress so that whenever you publish an article, your social media accounts also update. Very convenient. Below this option is a feature to sharing buttons. This avoids you having to deal with any code and the end result is also visually appealing as well. Even if you don’t get a lot of likes, this will still help your SEO.

All these steps listed above should help you create a better SEO strategy, remember to make your website useful or interesting and you should be rewarded with better views. Watch out for part 2 of this post & an upcoming best online SEO tools list.

 

Feature Image Designed by Dan Hetteix http://thenounproject.com/term/seo/28689/
